oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from P.J. Williamson to his wife, Eunice, during the Civil War, 1865 January 02
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A letter from Dutch immigrant, Peter J. Williamson, back home to his wife, Eunice, during the Civil War. In 1862 Williamson enlisted as a Private in the 1st Wisconsin Cavalry, Company F and was ultimately promoted to Full 1st Lieutenant. During the war, Williamson's regiment was involved in scouting and raids in Missouri and Arkansas and saw battle in the Middle Tennessee, Chickamauga, and Atlanta campaigns. In this letter from Nashville, Tennessee, Williamson writes that he arrived there on the preceding Thursday in good health. He reports that Nashville is full of people and he has taken the position of assistant architect in the Quartermaster's Department. He mentions his salary and compares it favorably to that of a Captain's salary. He discusses his boarding and the issues and expenses of getting them a house there. Williamson relates seeing Colonel La Grange and other officers arriving from Louisville. He closes by asking Eunice to write and wishes her a happy New Years. Forms part of the Peter J. Williamson Letters. 1 letter : col. ; 8 x 10 in.
